OF
WI. M. BURWELL, ESQ.
OF VIRGINIA,
ACCOMPANYING THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON ROUTES
It may not be improper, in addressing an Association to promote the industrial
interests of the Southwest, to show that the measures proposed for the developement
of our sectional prosperity will constitute the most effectual means of restoring our
political influence in the administration of the common government.
In the late conflict of sections the South has been more affected by the insult offered
to her institutions than by any apprehensions of their instability. But that conflict
has developed a relation between the progress and prosperity of the one section and
the dependence and decline of the other, entirely incompatible with that cordia
sentiment of harmony which should pervade, without regard to geographical divisions,
the whole
confederacy.
The South has been taught the practical truth, that in no age or nation have the
services or sacrifices of the past constituted a measure of sectional compensation, or a
oasis of operative power. Under our political relations, the names and deeds of the
Past are a national inheritance; but they are no more the acknowledged elements of
Political power, than the continental currency is an admitted evidence of a pecuniary
The people of the United States have determined to preserve the invaluable form of
Er.ernment endeared to them in its origin and in its operations. The South is desirous
